Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: Language Socialization, Education, and Social Transformation in a Context of Socioeconomic Inequality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will investigate the role of children's religious education in the spread of new norms of Islamic piety. The research is located in a formally secular state that is currently undergoing a popular religious revival. This project seeks to understand how reformist Islamic groups use informal neighborhood Quran schools to mold pious children. These schools are important venues for proselytizing politically and economically marginalized neighborhoods long stigmatized for a lack of proper piety. The researcher will examine how the piety taught in the schools affects everyday interactions among children, their families, and their neighbors, and contribute to the spread the Islamic Revival to new communities. This research uses methods in the study of language socialization to provide new insight on how moral subjects are formed in the context of everyday social interactions. The focus on the role of neighborhood schools in moral and religious proselytization will further our understanding of children as agents of social change.

By examining children's neighborhood Quran schools, this research addresses key questions in the anthropology of morality and religion: 1) how do individuals take on responsibility as moral subjects within a community and 2) how do the norms of a moral community change? Conducting research not only in the classroom, but also in the surrounding community, this project will observe how the children both learn explicit moral discourses and are drawn into the moral practices of everyday life. This research thus goes beyond the standard frameworks contrasting religion and secularism, and Islam and the West, to give us greater insight into the internal dynamics of change among Muslims during a time of major religious transformations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
University of Michigan doctoral student Nathaniel Tuohy, under the supervision of Dr. Webb Keane, investigated the role of children’s religious education in the spread of new norms of Islamic piety.  The research was located on the island of Java in the heart of Indonesia, where a secular democratic state governs the largest Muslim population of any nation in the world as it experiences ongoing popular religious revival. This project seeks to understand how reformist Islamic groups in the city of Yogyakarta use informal neighborhood Quran schools to mold “pious children”. These schools have become ubiquitous in neighborhoods throughout much of the nation. This research focused on their role as important venues for proselytizing poor neighborhoods long stigmatized for being home to impious ex-Communists, prostitutes, and small-time criminals. The researcher examined how the piety taught in the schools affects everyday interactions among children, their families, and their neighbors, and has contributed to the spread of the Islamic Revival to new communities in recent decades through the present. Using methods of ethnography and linguistic anthropology, the research was conducted in neighborhood communities and included observations children’s religious education as well as a range of neighborhood activities extending beyond the children’s Quran schools. The researcher’s observation of regional religious events such as children’s Islamic preaching contests, interviews with Muslim leaders outside of the communities of focus, and attention to broadcast and print media concerning children’s piety added context and bridged the gap between the local ethnography and national trends.

This research illuminated the mutual interaction of different national religious groups and grassroots activists in creating and sustaining the modern form of children’s Quran schools. It confirmed that religious education and revival cannot be separated from communal life, which includes regular interactions and events among neighbors, yet is also profoundly influenced by national political and religious trends. It also found that children are not merely vessels for the reproduction of unchanging religious norms; children are often key nodes of social and religious change.  By considering religious change in the context of community life and national politics in a dynamic democratic nation, this project helps go beyond the standard divide between religion and secularism, and Islam and the West, to give us greater insight into how religious norms change and spread.
